text: Hello everyone! I am Nikhil. I am interested in working on the vectorized implementation of NOVAS library in Julia. After a bit of searching, I found the C source code on <http://www.ascl.net/1202.003>. However, I could not find anything on GitHub so I'm not sure where to upload the code. Any help would be appreciated! I am currently going through the code base and plan to start implementing the custom data structures soon.

text: as far as I know there isn’t an implementation of this as a julia package. If the C library is easy to install, you use BinaryBuilder to create a wrapper library without having to reimplement anything

elements.text: as far as I know there isn’t an implementation of this as a julia package. If the C library is easy to install, you use BinaryBuilder to create a wrapper library without having to reimplement anything

text: I was planing to work on this as part of GSoC. The project goal stated that a vectorized version in Julia was needed. So I'm not sure that would work.

text: Oh, I see now- sorry I didn’t realize! I’ll actually let <@UDB26738Q> or <@ULSFQ48UQ> give you a better response since they’re the mentors for the project.

text: <@U01RKQG7A72> hi, sorry for the late reply! Welcome here! For the details of the GSoC project I'll leave it to Paul, but feel free to ask any questions about Julia or the JuliaAstro organisation! :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: hi, sorry for the late reply! Welcome here! For the details of the GSoC project I'll leave it to Paul, but feel free to ask any questions about Julia or the JuliaAstro organisation!

text: Sorry, just saw this thread. There is no public implementation yet, so we are free to implement as best we see fit. You should review the C code. It also helps to have access to the “Explanatory Supplement to the Astronomical Almanac”, that contains most of the equations.

elements.text: Sorry, just saw this thread. There is no public implementation yet, so we are free to implement as best we see fit. You should review the C code. It also helps to have access to the “Explanatory Supplement to the Astronomical Almanac”, that contains most of the equations.

text: I have started going through the C code. I am simultaneously also implementing the basic functions which do not require any astronomy knowledge.

text: good!  out of curiosity, do you already have experience with Julia? :slightly_smiling_face:

text: I've been working on a project at my Institute on Boolean Symbolic Computation. I have a bit of experience from there.

text:
I've started with the basic implementation. I will keep it updated at <https://github.com/cnikhil3/NOVAS-JULIA>. <@ULSFQ48UQ> The OpenAstronomy GSoC page says that a pull request is needed for applying. But given the nature of this project, I do not think it is possible. However, I do plan to complete a significant portion of the basic implementation by the time application period ends. I was wondering if that would be sufficient.
P.S. This is my first time contributing to open-source.

text: <@U01RKQG7A72> The Student Application Period is March 29 - April 13. Then there is an application review period and accepted students are chosen on May 17. Several students are interested in working on this project, so I suggest that you submit an application before doing any work.

elements.text: The Student Application Period is March 29 - April 13. Then there is an application review period and accepted students are chosen on May 17. Several students are interested in working on this project, so I suggest that you submit an application before doing any work.

text: Okay sir. I have started working on my application and will share that soon. Please let me know if I should look for an issue in other organisations of OpenAstronomy to satisfy the criteria of having a pull request.
